textContent:
Each "quest" or, more aptly named, encounter, has a few state machines that relate to the player's knowledge or past choices. This is best illustrated with a diagram. In the "states imply" picture, you can see that the logical flow of the states dictates that, if you have seen the Wolf, you surely know about the Wolf.

This should be used to keep track of what players have done, where they've been, what they know, etc. Every time they do a relevant action to an encounter, it should be flagged. Thus, whenever there's an opportunity for taking that set flag and turning it into part of the player's story, we have the means to do it.

With this system, given that you can keep track of what the player knows, you can use it to reveal information or play events in a decentralized manner. 
For example: You want to become a Bassadyan spy. In order to do so, you must reveal what happened to the Empress. For such task, you can extort courtesans, personal guards, find secret registries, etc. Instead of each one having their own particular secret, they reveal the next secret that you don't know, lending itself to a better storytelling, guaranteeing that the structure of the story is always the best. (see image "State trees").
This can also be used for discovering abilities. In the image, a Scholar learns how to open enchanted doors and chests by learning about what it is, how it works and how to open it.
